definitions.Ender: A truth claim about the world which one believes to be true.
A truth claim which accurately describes sense perception, both in the content and the literal relationship between thoughts and the 5 main senses.
Memory (which makes "self-knowledge" "self-memory", which is an oxymoron).
What one believes oneself to be, which are inherently emotional due to the nature of self-belief.
Conscious experience occurring now.
Events which happened previously, but only are subjectively experienced as a thought now (never truly experienced).
Events which are expected to happen, but are only subjectively experienced as a thought now (never truly experienced).
The existence of sensory perception (this is a panpsychist worldview, Jamie might say "physical reality").
Physical sensations in the body that are internally generated by evaluating sensory perception or thinking.
The default mode of experience where one has no negative beliefs about oneself that are currently operating.
The belief that something has wronged you.
Present oneness of experience which facilitates naturally caring and altruistic behavior.
Evaluating one scenario to be favorable to another (which necessarily stems from not recognizing the oneness of experience, so there is nothing to compare in the first place).
Evaluating one scenario to be less favorable to another (which necessarily stems from not recognizing the oneness of experience, so there is nothing to compare in the first place).
Good in terms of a sensory experience.
Bad in terms of a sensory experience.
The fact of content appearing in awareness.

A narrative created by thinking to describe a past event. An incorrect use of interpretation is what leads to the self-image which is often described as "experiencing things twice" (once as the event, another time as the interpretation).
The belief that one has caused unnecessary suffering, which encourages the mind to learn to not cause unnecessary suffering (not necessarily tied to self-image).
The belief that one is insufficient (tied to self-image).

The belief that one's current experience could extremely conceivably be better if some process was more efficient (necessarily tied to self-image since it stems from a failure to recognize the oneness of experience).
The belief that efforts are not leading to the intended results (not necessarily tied to self-image).
The sequential passage of events that is not directly experienced.
The ability to recognize and correct errors in thinking.

answers.Jamie: Self-realization is recognizing that there is no separate self — no internal entity controlling experience. It's the direct seeing that thoughts, emotions, and sensations arise on their own without a 'you' behind them. It's not something you achieve; it's recognizing what has always been the case. The self-image — the story of who you are — is just a collection of thoughts and emotions, not an actual entity.

faq.question: Would you force self-realization on others if you could?

answers.Jamie: No. Forcing someone into self-realization would be like forcing someone to see an optical illusion — it doesn't work that way. It has to be seen for oneself. And honestly, people need to come to it in their own time. You can point, you can describe, but the seeing has to happen on its own. Forcing understanding is a contradiction.

No, not in the way most people mean it. Loneliness requires a self-image — a 'me' that feels separate and lacking connection. Without that self-image, there's just experience. Sometimes there's solitude, which is just the factual state of being alone, but there's no emotional suffering attached to it. The ache of loneliness comes from believing you're a separate entity that needs something from others to be complete.

There is experience, but there is no experiencer separate from experience. The 'self' is a thought — a mental construct. When you look for the self, you only find thoughts about a self, emotions about a self, but never the self itself. It's like looking for the corner of a circle. The search itself reveals that what you're looking for was never there to begin with.

faq.question: Can experience truly be expressed in words?

answers.Jamie: No. Words are symbols that point to experience, but they are not experience itself. Describing the taste of chocolate to someone who has never tasted it will never convey the actual experience. All of our communication is approximation. This is especially true for self-realization — you can describe it endlessly, but the description is never the thing. The map is not the territory.

Thoughts arise on their own. You don't choose your next thought — if you did, you'd need a thought before the thought to decide what to think, leading to infinite regress. Thoughts are spontaneous appearances in awareness, like sounds or sights. The illusion is that there's a 'thinker' generating them, but when you look carefully, thoughts just appear and disappear on their own.

faq.question: Do good emotions go away after self-realization?

answers.Jamie: No. Emotions still happen — joy, excitement, warmth, all of it. What changes is that there's no self-image claiming ownership of them or needing them to continue. Good emotions aren't suppressed; they actually become more vivid because there's no mental commentary layered on top. What goes away is the suffering that comes from clinging to good feelings or fearing their loss.

faq.question: Does understanding continue to evolve after self-realization?

answers.Jamie: Yes, absolutely. Self-realization isn't the end of learning or growth. The mind still refines its understanding, still learns, still adapts. What changes is that learning isn't driven by a self-image trying to become better or more enlightened. It's just the natural functioning of intelligence — recognizing and correcting errors in thinking. Understanding deepens continuously.

faq.question: Why don't you need a self-image?

answers.Jamie: Because the self-image doesn't do anything useful. It's not what makes decisions — decisions happen through the natural process of thinking. It's not what drives action — the body acts based on the totality of its conditioning and present circumstances. The self-image only creates suffering by generating emotions based on stories about who you are. Without it, everything still functions — actually, it functions better because there's no internal friction.

faq.question: Does self-realization happen all at once or gradually?

answers.Jamie: The recognition itself is instantaneous — either you see it or you don't, like an optical illusion clicking into place. But the unwinding of habitual patterns of thought and emotion can take time. Old habits of self-referential thinking don't vanish overnight. So the seeing is sudden, but the integration is gradual. The self-image doesn't go away in one dramatic moment; it erodes as its mechanisms are seen through again and again.

faq.question: How do I engage with self-realization?

answers.Jamie: Start by questioning your assumptions about yourself. When you feel an emotion, ask: who is feeling this? When you have a thought, notice that it appeared on its own. Look for the self that you assume is there. Not as a meditation technique or practice, but as genuine curiosity. The whole thing is about looking honestly at your direct experience rather than accepting the stories your mind tells about it.

faq.question: Do you experience grief or loss?

answers.Jamie: There can be sadness when someone or something is gone — that's a natural response. But it's not the same as grief driven by self-image, where you're suffering because 'my life is worse now' or 'I've lost part of myself.' Without the self-image component, sadness is clean — it arises, it's felt fully, and it passes. There's no prolonged suffering story wrapped around it.

faq.question: What is the ego and how does it relate to love?

answers.Jamie: The ego is just the self-image — the collection of beliefs about who and what you are. It's not an entity; it's a pattern of thinking. Love, real love, has nothing to do with the ego. What most people call love is actually ego-based attachment: 'I love you because you make me feel good about myself.' Actual love is what remains when the self-image isn't filtering experience — it's the natural state of caring that arises from recognizing the oneness of experience.

faq.question: What is the root of discontent?

answers.Jamie: The root of all discontent is the self-image. Every form of psychological suffering can be traced back to a belief about yourself — that you're not enough, that you need something, that something is wrong. Without these self-referential beliefs, there's just experience happening. Experience itself is never the problem. It's the story about how experience affects 'me' that creates suffering.

Ambition driven by self-image — 'I need to prove myself' or 'I need to become someone' — naturally falls away. But that doesn't mean you become passive. Action still happens, goals still get pursued, but they come from genuine interest and the natural movement of life rather than from a desperate need to fill a hole in your self-image. You might actually accomplish more because there's no internal resistance or fear of failure getting in the way.

It wasn't one dramatic event. It was a gradual process of questioning that reached a tipping point. I spent time looking at the nature of thought, examining emotions, questioning the assumptions I had about being a separate self. At some point, the whole structure just became transparent — I could see that the self I had taken to be real was just a pattern of thinking. Once seen, it can't be unseen, though the old patterns still took time to fully unwind.

faq.question: What are your thoughts on Dr. K (HealthyGamerGG)?

answers.Jamie: Dr. K does good work in making mental health accessible, but his framework is still operating within the assumption of a self that needs to be fixed or improved. He's helping people manage their self-image better, which reduces suffering to a degree, but it doesn't address the root cause. It's like giving someone better furniture for a house that's on fire — helpful in the short term, but not addressing the fundamental issue.
